tossups.question: In this poem, a list of "Bodies chang'd to various Forms" includes men who "prove with child," "maids turn'd bottles," "living teapots," and a "pipkin" that walks. This poem's dedication names the occult book Le Comte de Gabalis as a source for the "machinery" within. In this poem, a bag filled with items such as the "Force of Female Lungs" and the "War of Tongues," which is poured on a woman found weeping in Thalestris's arms, is granted by the Queen of the Cave of Spleen to the gnome Umbriel. After a game of ombre at Hampton Court, the Baron uses a "forfex" on the central character of this poem, who is protected by Ariel and an army of sylphs. The line "what mighty quarrels rise from trivial things" completes the first heroic couplet of this poem. For 10 points, name this "mock-epic" about stolen hair, by Alexander Pope.

These people were the first to use polychrome slip before firing pottery to create objects such as the double spout and bridge vessel. The evolution of these people's pottery is divided into "monumental" and "proliferous" phases. These people created the "Great Cloth," which was found at a site excavated by Giuseppe Orefici (or-EFF-itch-ee). These people were theorized to have built the first puquios (pook-EE-ohs), which were underground aqueducts. Paul Kosok and Maria Reiche (RAI-keh) mapped structures created by these people. Many "trophy heads" were found at this culture's site of Cahuachi (kah-WAH-chee). Jim Woodman theorized that these people may have built the first hot air balloon in order to view from above geoglyphs that they created. For 10 points, identify this culture which created symbols in the Peruvian desert known as their namesake "lines".

A concertante piano piece by this composer depicts a chatelaine waiting for a knight's return from the Crusades. This composer, who called for an early use of multiphonics in an E minor horn concertino, wrote an F major bassoon concerto numbered 127 by Jähns and only second in popularity to Mozart's. Mozart failed to woo this composer's cousin Aloysia, then married her sister Constanze. An "alla polacca" rondo closes this composer's second concerto for Heinrich Baermann on clarinet. The first true Western use of an Asian tune appears in this composer's incidental music for a translation of Gozzi's Turandot, as quoted in Hindemith's Symphonic Metamorphosis. For a French production of his most popular opera, Hector Berlioz orchestrated this German's Invitation to the Dance. For 10 points, name this proto-Romantic composer of Der Freischutz.
tossups.formatted_answer: Carl Maria von Weber [or Karl Maria Friedrich Ernst von Weber]
tossups.answer: Carl Maria von Weber [or Karl Maria Friedrich Ernst von Weber]

tossups.question: C. K. Jørgensen identified "suspect" examples of these chemical species that make resulting oxidation states unclear. Electrons are transferred from another species' bonding orbital to an antibonding orbital in these species when they act as pi-acceptors. Bulky examples of these species have a high cone angle. Introducing these species lowers the Racah B parameter in the nephelauxetic effect, which is not accounted for in a namesake theory that uses molecular orbital theory to augment the predictions of d-orbital splitting from crystal field theory. The Greek letter mu denotes bridging examples of these species, while eta denotes their hapticity. When polydentate, these species act as chelating ("key-LAY-ting") agents. For 10 points, name these chemical species bound to the metal atom center of a coordination complex.
tossups.formatted_answer: ligands (LIG-unds) [accept non-innocent ligands; accept bulky ligands; accept polydentate ligands; prompt on chelates or chelating agents before mention]
tossups.answer: ligands (LIG-unds) [accept non-innocent ligands; accept bulky ligands; accept polydentate ligands; prompt on chelates or chelating agents before mention]

tossups.question: A member of this group called the "C.O." tells Raymond Boyle that the Milky Way has died. Characters in this group laugh when they are told that they are the glory of the Universe in a story satirizing the Protocols of the Elders of Zion. A member of this group named Salo operates a vessel powered by the Universal Will to Believe and implants a hallucination into the dying mind of Malachi Constant. This group's members are described as "shaped like plumber's friends" and have "a little hand with a green eye in its palm." Members of this group, who can see in four dimensions, summarize their fatalist philosophy by responding to deaths with "so it goes." This group kidnaps Hollywood star Montana Wildhack and keeps her in a zoo with Billy Pilgrim. For 10 points, name this alien race that appears in many Kurt Vonnegut novels.
tossups.formatted_answer: Tralfamadorians [or word forms; prompt on aliens or equivalents]
tossups.answer: Tralfamadorians [or word forms; prompt on aliens or equivalents]

tossups.question: In The Realm of Understanding, a non-Nazi Karl Schmidt stated that the individual is the final result of a process described by this philosopher. This philosopher used the example of water boiling to illustrate how a change in quality does not necessarily result in a change in quantity, whose transition he dubbed "measure." Alexandre Kojève argued that a figure theorized by this thinker is the key to historical progress because they alone can experience "self-consciousness". This philosopher theorized a process of sublation through which the contradictions of "Being" and "Nothing" were resolved in their transformation into "Becoming." For 10 points, name this thinker whose dialectic method, often summarized with the formula "thesis-antithesis-synthesis," in presented in his Phenomenology of Spirit.

This man is the subject of podcaster Mike Duncan's 2021 book, which contains an interlude called "The Prisoners of Olmutz." This man was arrested in the Austrian Netherlands after Georges Danton issued a warrant for his arrest, leading Angelica Schuyler Church to help him briefly escape captivity. During the Day of Daggers, this man worked to stop armed nobles from storming the Tuileries (TOO-luh-ree) Palace as head of the National Guard. After a meeting with Silas Deane, this man bought his own ship, the Victoire (vik-TWAH), to transport him across the Atlantic Ocean. This man wrote the first drafts of the Declaration of Rights of the Man and the Citizen with help from his friend Thomas Jefferson. For 10 points, name this Frenchman called the "Hero of Two Worlds" for his integral roles in the French and American Revolutions.

In a Conor Oberst song, this man agrees on "where prisons should be built and filled" when he "talks to God." Fat Mike of NOFX organized punk musicians for a project titled Rock Against [this man]. Thom Yorke used a phrase mocking this man as the title of a 2003 Radiohead album. The song "Not Ready to Make Nice" is addressed to this man, the target of comments by Natalie Maines that caused The Chicks' cover of "Landslide" to fall off the Billboard Hot 100. In 2022, this man delivered a Freudian slip regarding the "decision of one man" in Ukraine. Early Flash games allowed players to re-enact a journalist throwing his shoe at this man. A fundraising broadcast rapidly cut to Chris Tucker after a rapper stated that this man "doesn't care about Black people." For 10 points, Kanye West criticized which President's poor handling of Hurricane Katrina?
tossups.formatted_answer: George W. Bush [or Bush 43; prompt on partial answers; prompt on Rock Against Bush; prompt on answers referring to the President of the United States with "which one?"; do not accept or prompt on "George H.W. Bush" or "Bush 41"] [The Radiohead album is Hail to the Thief.]
tossups.answer: George W. Bush [or Bush 43; prompt on partial answers; prompt on Rock Against Bush; prompt on answers referring to the President of the United States with "which one?"; do not accept or prompt on "George H.W. Bush" or "Bush 41"] [The Radiohead album is Hail to the Thief.]

tossups.question: M. E. Stern explained atmospheric blocking by studying pairs of these features called "modons." The restratification that leads to the North Atlantic Algal Bloom may result from these features' namesake "pumping." Mesoscale examples of these features which appear each winter off British Columbia are named for Haida (HIGH-dah). Meteorologists often use a CFD technique that uses these objects' namesake "viscosity" and is named for simulating large examples of them. A type of these phenomena called "core rings" form by splitting off from ocean currents. Potholes are carved out when pebbles are stuck in small examples of these features, which form behind boulders in rivers. Kayakers use these water features to rest when descending rapids, as they produce opposing currents to the river flow. For 10 points, name these chaotic circular fluid flows.
tossups.formatted_answer: eddies [or eddy or mesoscale eddies or large eddy simulation or eddy viscosity or Haida eddies or eddy dipoles or eddy pumping; or warm core rings until "core rings" is read; prompt on vortices or vortex]
tossups.answer: eddies [or eddy or mesoscale eddies or large eddy simulation or eddy viscosity or Haida eddies or eddy dipoles or eddy pumping; or warm core rings until "core rings" is read; prompt on vortices or vortex]

tossups.question: It's not the Beast, but bees fly around one of this figure's seven heads in a woodcut by Hans Brosamer. The dead bodies of Aristotle and four other philosophers appear below this figure in a caricature as Hercules by Hans Holbein the Younger. This figure points to a book as blood falls on a self-portrait of an artist in the central panel of the Weimar Altarpiece. Because of a prophecy at the Council of Constance, this figure is often depicted with a swan. A Hans Baldung Grien woodcut of this figure as a saint inspired a lament to him by Albrecht Dürer. An artist represented by a winged serpent shared his printing presses with this man. This man appears in a black robe with a floppy hat in many portraits by his friend Lucas Cranach the Elder. For 10 points, Cranach also made 22 woodcuts for the Bible translation by what German reformer?

A semi-autobiographical film from this country was inspired by its director stabbing a policeman during a protest. Another film from this country follows a pizza delivery driver who attempts to rob a jewelry store whose owner was rude to him earlier in the film. A director from this setting of A Moment of Innocence and Crimson Gold established a style of setting a camera on the dashboard of a car and recording unknowing citizens for the background of his Koker Trilogy. The legal case of a movie-obsessed impersonator of Mohsen Makhmalbaf in this country appears in the film Close-Up. Two women in chadors (CHA-dors) confront a girl about buying heavy metal contraband in this country in an animated French language film. For 10 points, name this home country of Abbas Kiarostami and the setting of Marjane (mar-JAH-neh) Satrapi's Persepolis.

The narrator of a novel describes a morning "in the early spring of 1915" when one of these objects hits a "frost-hardened tussock of earth," causing three drops of blood to turn into rubies. While attempting to pray, the grandfather Aadam Aziz (adam ah-ZEEZ) damages one of these objects. One of these objects becomes able to detect emotions after a drainage operation, and its powers allow a novel's protagonist to organize a "conference." In a short story, Zenchi Naigu stomps on one of these objects to shrink it. A seer prophesies a large, cucumber-shaped one of these body parts, alongside knees belonging to Shiva, that grants Saleem Sinai telepathy in Midnight's Children. In another story, Ivan Yakovlevich discovers this body part in a loaf of bread. For 10 points, name this body part that titles short stories by Ryunosuke Akutagawa and Nikolai Gogol.

A philosopher of this religion opposed a different religious thinker's denial of the veracity of either of the "two truths" in advocating the soul's pure "ultimate perspective" over the delusional "mundane perspective" in his book The Essence of the Doctrine. A verse treatise from this religion that lists the existence, permanence, and agency of the soul among "six steps" was written by a thinker called "Kavi" by a thinker from another religion in the latter's memoir on "experimenting" with truth. Kundakunda and Rajchandra followed this religion, whose logicians advised using the word "syad" to mean "maybe" and created a seven-valued logic. This religion regards truth as "many-sided," and lists not stealing, celibacy, and non-possessiveness among its five vows. For 10 points, name this dharmic religion whose three pillars include ahimsa.
tossups.formatted_answer: Jainism [or Jain Dharma; or Svetambara or Digambara Jainism] [Rajchandra mentored Mahatma Gandhi, as recounted in the autobiography The Story of My Experiments with Truth]
tossups.answer: Jainism [or Jain Dharma; or Svetambara or Digambara Jainism] [Rajchandra mentored Mahatma Gandhi, as recounted in the autobiography The Story of My Experiments with Truth]

tossups.question: This person ordered Robert Hodgson hanged by his thumbs after Hodgson was arrested for preaching. This administrator paid a ransom of powder and lead to retrieve women and children who were captured during the Peach War. This person appointed nine men to an assembly appropriately called The Nine Men. This man's persecution of Quakers led to a petition addressed to him called the Flushing Remonstrance. The name of The Bowery neighborhood was inspired by a farm owned by this man, who was badly wounded in his right leg by a cannon shot on the island of Saint Martin. This man, who succeeded Willem Kieft (VIL-em keeft) in 1647, led the troops that besieged Fort Christina and forced New Sweden to surrender. For 10 points, name this final Director General of New Netherland, who was nicknamed "Peg Leg Pete."
tossups.formatted_answer: Peter Stuyvesant [or Pieter Stuyvesant; or Petrus Stuyvesant; or Pete Stuyvesant]
tossups.answer: Peter Stuyvesant [or Pieter Stuyvesant; or Petrus Stuyvesant; or Pete Stuyvesant]

tossups.question: In 2007, the Belle experiment detected an unusual one of these particles called Z1.30) ("zee forty-four thirty"). The physicist and mountaineer Giuseppe Occhialini (JUH-zep-eh ock-ya-LEEN-ee) placed emulsions high in the Alps in which the first of these particles were discovered. The 1974 "November Revolution" in particle physics was prompted by the independent discoveries of a neutral one of these particles by Burton Richter and Samuel Ting. Studying the decay of some of these particles led to Cronin and Fitch discovering CP violation. Before it was found to be fundamental, the muon was thought to be one of these particles, whose types include the J/psi (jay-"sigh") particle. These highly unstable particles are bosons, in contrast to baryons, which are fermions. Kaons (KAY-onz) and pions are types of - for 10 points - what hadrons made up of a quark and an antiquark?
tossups.formatted_answer: mesons [or mesonic resonance; or tetraquarks or pions or kaons or J/psi particles or psions until they are read; prompt on hadrons until it is read]
tossups.answer: mesons [or mesonic resonance; or tetraquarks or pions or kaons or J/psi particles or psions until they are read; prompt on hadrons until it is read]

tossups.question: Myiagros, or Myacoris, is a divine figure often invoked to deal with these creatures during animal sacrifices. A figure driven towards Prometheus by the torment of one of these creatures is told by the titan they'd be the ancestor to Heracles, after which that figure travels to Egypt. During Heracles' tenth labor, Hera sends one of these creatures to scatter Geryon's cattle. To avoid a prophecy, Zeus transformed Metis into one of these creatures and swallowed her. Io is constantly stung by one of these creatures after being transformed into a bull. Following an intervention from this creature sent by the gods, a hero lives out his life in misery after being blinded in the Plain of Aleion by a thorn bush he fell into. Bellerophon is thrown off Pegasus by the bite of, for 10 points, what type of insect?
tossups.formatted_answer: flies [or fly; or gadfly, prompt on such answers as insect or bug]
tossups.answer: flies [or fly; or gadfly, prompt on such answers as insect or bug]

tossups.question: Muslims of this ethnicity were targeted in the Nellie massacre that occurred amidst the Assam Agitation. Refugees of this ethnicity were driven out of forests in the Marichjhapi incident (mah-REECH-jah-pee). The far-right militia Al-Badr participated in the mass execution of intellectuals of this ethnicity in 1971. Viceroy Archibald Wavell attempted to help people of this ethnicity who were suffering from conditions exacerbated by two "denial policies." Operation Searchlight was launched to crush this ethnic group's nationalist movement. Physicist Satyendra Nath Bose and writer Rabindranath Tagore (rah-BIN-drah-naht tah-GOOR) were part of this ethnicity's "Renaissance." Winston Churchill's limited aid led up to 3.8 million people of this ethnicity to die in a 1943 famine. For 10 points, what subcontinental ethnic group names an Indian state and a country on a namesake bay?

The protagonist of a play by this author works for Sigelius at the Lilienthal Clinic and is killed by a crowd shouting, "We want war!" In another play by this author, a woman who uses pseudonyms with the initials "E. M." proves pivotal to the case Gregor v. Prus. Galen fails to save the Marshal from the "white disease" in another play by this author. This author created a representative from the Humanity League who burns a secret formula in one play, and wrote about an immortality-granting potion in The Makropulos Secret. In this author's most famous play, Alquist calls Primus and Helena the new Adam and Eve. In that play by this author, Harry Domin manages a company that creates the title artificial people, who stage a revolt against humankind. For 10 points, name this Czech playwright of R.U.R.

This structure's epithelium contains wing cells. Mooren's ulcer disrupts this structure. Viral infections of this structure can cause pseudo-dendrites or dendrites, and a "ring infiltrate" appears when this structure is infected by Acanthamoeba (a-CAN-thuh-MEE-buh). Bowman's membrane protects this structure. This structure suffers from amyloid buildup in lattice dystrophy, while it gradually degenerates in Fuchs' (FEWKS) dystrophy. A fluorescein (floor-ESS-in) stain is used to diagnose C·M·V or H·S·V infection of this structure, which is called keratitis. This body part's namesake limbus is where it meets the sclera. This structure is avascular, so it gets its nutrients from the aqueous humor. An excimer laser is used to reshape this structure in LASIK surgery, and it has more refractive power than the lens. For 10 points, name this clear outer portion of the eyeball.

An "amoral" focus on this institution in "Montegrano" is discussed in Edward Banfield's The Moral Basis of a Backward Society. In an 1884 book, the shift from "savagery" to "barbarism" and "civilization" is traced to transitions to this institution's "punaluan" and "pairing" forms due to the rise of private property. Conflict directed towards this entity by work is generated through the title "second shift" of an Arlie Hochschild book. This institution's collapse among African Americans is the subject of the Moynihan Report. Research on matrifocal examples of this institution is cited in a book on "The Origins of" this thing, private property and the state by Friedrich Engels. For 10 points, namesake "ties" are described with kinship terminology for what institution whose "nuclear" type is limited to a husband, wife, and their children?
tossups.formatted_answer: the family [or kinship before mention; or household; or amoral familialism; or The Origins of the Family, Private Property, and the State; or work-to-family conflict; or The Negro Family; or family ties; or nuclear family; prompt on marriage]
tossups.answer: the family [or kinship before mention; or household; or amoral familialism; or The Origins of the Family, Private Property, and the State; or work-to-family conflict; or The Negro Family; or family ties; or nuclear family; prompt on marriage]

tossups.question: Pozzolanic activity is measured through the reaction rate of pozzolans with this ion in the presence of water. This ion and a lighter counterpart are the primary targets for "builders" added to detergents. This ion is bonded to chlorine in a compound used in most guard tube experiments. Sodium and this ion complex with EDTA to form a treatment for lead poisoning. This ion's sulfate exhibits retrograde solubility, prompting the use of descaling agents in many boilers. This cation is found in "burnt" and "slaked" compounds commonly used to increase soil pH. Along with magnesium, this is the most prevalent ion found in hard water. For 10 points, name this monatomic cation, which bonds with carbonate to form the major constituent of limestone.

bonuses.leadin: In the 1950s and 60s, Jock Campbell worked to reform this company's estates in British Guinea, which was often called this company's Guinea due to the dominant role it played in the colony's economy. For 10 points each:
parts: A 1972 speech by John Berger criticizes what company for monopolizing Guyana's colonial sugar production?

British Guinea's Demerara Rebellion, which took place in sugar plantations, contributed to 1833 legislation accomplishing this goal. John Gladstone, who owned plantations in Jamaica and Guinea, was the largest recipient of this legislation's consequent payouts.

In Guyanese plantations, John Gladstone pioneered the use of vacuum pans to maximize sugar production, whose leftover molasses was often converted into this alcoholic drink prevalent in the Caribbean.
answers: United Kingdom's outlaw of slavery [or abolition or other answers referring to ending slavery in the British Empire]
formatted_answers: United Kingdom's outlaw of slavery [or abolition or other answers referring to ending slavery in the British Empire]

bonuses.leadin: The ancient Egyptians called their land kemet, literally meaning "land" of this color. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this color that symbolized new life and resurrection in ancient Egypt as inspired by the fertile nutrients deposited by the Nile River. The Nubians were often painted this color in Egyptian art.
Due to their connections with fertility, Osiris and this father of his were often painted green or black. This deity married a goddess of the sky.
The hieroglyph for the color black is typically identified as part of this creature. A deity with the head of this creature was the patron of the Egyptian army.

bonuses.leadin: Children's description of these places as "where you go to die" is reported between accounts of "holy mouth men" and "listeners" in a 1956 paper. For 10 points each:
parts: Give the Nacirema term for these temples where medicine men use "magically treated needles" on neophytes whose excreta are collected by vestal maidens to divine illnesses.

Horace Miner's essay on the Nacirema latipso, or American hospital, is taught to promote this anthropological approach credited to Franz Boas but coined by Alain Locke. It opposes ethnocentrism by evaluating cultures on their own terms.

Keith Quincy's book on this Asian ethnic group is cited throughout The Spirit Catches You and You Fall Down, which records how a lack of cultural competence prevented the treatment of the epileptic Lia Lee in a Merced hospital.

bonuses.leadin: This magazine published William Parker's slave narrative "The Freedman's Story" and Julia Ward Howe's "Battle Hymn of the Republic." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this magazine still in print, which was founded by Boston abolitionists and named for a nearby body of water.
This author promoted realist literature as editor of The Atlantic. This "Dean of American Letters" wrote a realist novel titled for the Rise of materialistic paint magnate Silas Lapham.

Howells's successor Thomas Bailey Aldrich published many of this author's stories, including "The Goophered (GOO-ferd) Grapevine," in which Dugal McAdoo hires Aunt Peggy to curse his scuppernong grapes. This author challenged the "plantation tradition" in the story collection The Conjure Woman.

bonuses.leadin: A 2009 study by Sunamura, Espadaler et al. found that the largest known polydomous example of these structures stretches across Japan, California and Europe. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify these structures which Walter Tschinkel studies with aluminum casts. These structures are modeled by formicariums, better known as their namesake eusocial insects' "farms."

The idea of superorganisms such as ant colonies is extended to a global scale by the Gaia hypothesis that James Lovelock developed with this biologist. Her paper "On the Origin of Mitosing Cells" advanced the endosymbiotic theory of mitochondria and chloroplasts.
This is the term for brood parasitic ants, such as Formica sanguinea, that steal larvae from other ant colonies to increase the size of their workforce.
answers: ant colony [or ant colonies; or ant hills; accept supercolonies or megacolonies; prompt on ant farms]
Lynn Margulis [accept Lynn Peter Alexander; accept Lynn Sagan (then married to Carl Sagan)]
formatted_answers: ant colony [or ant colonies; or ant hills; accept supercolonies or megacolonies; prompt on ant farms]
Lynn Margulis [accept Lynn Peter Alexander; accept Lynn Sagan (then married to Carl Sagan)]

bonuses.leadin: In this novel, Carlene gives Hector Hyppolite's painting Maitresse Erzulie to Kiki before dying of cancer. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this novel. This novel centers on the feud between the conservative Christian Monty Kipps and the liberal head of the Belsey family.
The Kipps, who appear in Zadie Smith's On Beauty, move to the fictional town of Wellington from this country. Smith, who is from this country, set both NW and White Teeth in this country's capital.
Smith styled On Beauty as an "homage" to this other novel. Carlene's gift of the Hippolyte painting to Kiki mirrors how the Wilcox house is bequeathed to Margaret Schlegel in this novel.
answers: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland [or U.K.; or Great Britain; or England]
formatted_answers: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland [or U.K.; or Great Britain; or England]

bonuses.leadin: Three of the four Kepler-Poinsot (PWAN-soh) polyhedra are the "great," "small stellated," and "great stellated" variants of this shape. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this polyhedron, which has a similar shape to the pyritohedron structure of certain iron pyrite crystals. It has 20 vertices and 30 edges.
Armand Spitz used a dodecahedron shape for his widespread planetarium projectors based on a suggestion by this German scientist, who had earlier stated that "E equals m c squared."

The fossil Braarudosphaera bigelowii (brar-roo-doh-S'FAIR-ah big-el-OH-eye), which is shaped like a perfect regular dodecahedron, is one of these unicellular phytoplankton, whose namesake calcium carbonate scales form a major part of limestone.

bonuses.leadin: Many French troops left this modern-day country after losing the Battle of Vertières (vair-tee-AIR). For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Caribbean country whose independence was declared at Gonaïves (goh-nah-EEV) by Jean-Jacques Dessalines (day-sah-leen) in 1804, less than one year after the death of Toussaint Louverture (too-SAN loo-vair-TOOR).

During the Haitian Revolution, André Rigaud (ree-goh) was exiled to France following his loss in 1800 to Louverture in a conflict named the "War of" these objects. Seven years earlier, a woman smuggled one of these objects into the home of the editor of The Friend of the People in her corset.
The Haitian Revolution began in 1791 shortly after this Vodou (voh-doo) priest officiated a ceremony at Bois Caïman (bwah kah-ee-MON) that included the drinking of blood from a sacrificed pig.
answers: knife [or knives; or War of Knives] [Charlotte Corday brought a knife to kill Jean Paul Marat]
formatted_answers: knife [or knives; or War of Knives] [Charlotte Corday brought a knife to kill Jean Paul Marat]

bonuses.leadin: Cyclone Mekunu allowed these insects to breed undetected in temporary lakes in Saudi Arabia's Empty Quarter. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these insects that have devastated agriculture in eastern Africa since 2019, due to their continual "swarms."
In 2020, this body gave an estimate of $1 billion for the costs of the swarms if they were left uncontrolled. This body was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 2020.

The WFP organized a truce in this region to deliver humanitarian to 2 million starving people in Mekelle. "Defense Forces" from this region of northern Ethiopia partnered with the Oromo Liberation Front to fight Abiy Ahmed's federal forces.

bonuses.leadin: This thinker wrote on the "against" side against J.J.C. Smart in the dialogue volume Utilitarianism: For and Against. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this English moral philosopher who wrote Ethics and the Limits of Philosophy. He discussed Gauguin's move to Tahiti in a paper coining the term "moral luck."
J. J. C. Smart criticized this utilitarian school as "restricted". Smart contrasted "extreme" "act utilitarianism" with this other approach, which judges actions based on their underlying principles.
Smart contrasted his more modern "preference" utilitarianism with the "hedonism" of this formulator of the greatest happiness principle, who mentored John Stuart Mill and founded utilitarianism

bonuses.leadin: Despite hoping that it could be used to treat cancer, this element's discoverer died in 1975 from bone cancer caused by it. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this last element to be discovered in nature. Marguerite Perey ("perry") discovered this alkali metal, which has the largest atomic radius of any element.

As Perey wasn't allowed to present her discovery to the Académie des Sciences ("ah-cah-DAY-mee day see-ONSS"), the presentation was done by this man. This scientist used Einstein's work on Brownian motion to determine Avogadro's number.

Perey named francium with the help of a member of this family. Perey started out as an assistant to a scientist from this family who had co-discovered polonium and radium, winning two Nobel Prizes in the process.
answers: Curie family [accept Joliot or Joliot-Curie or Skłodowska; accept Irène Joliot-Curie or Marie Salomea Skłodowska–Curie]
formatted_answers: Curie family [accept Joliot or Joliot-Curie or Skłodowska; accept Irène Joliot-Curie or Marie Salomea Skłodowska–Curie]

bonuses.leadin: The only surviving music of cantigas from this kingdom are by Martin Codax and his king. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this kingdom ruled by the "poet king" Denis. Though frequently nicknamed for Spain, "La Folia" originated in this neighboring kingdom.

King John IV wrote a defense of the style of this Italian composer popularized by Johann Fux's counterpoint treatise Gradus ad Parnassum. A legend about this composer provides the plot of a Hans Pfitzner opera.

Portugal's foremost "golden age" polyphonists were John IV, Duarte Lobo, and Manuel Cardoso, who experimented with this other texture of call-and-response music. This texture of Tomas Luis de Victoria's experiments with polychoral style is named for chants sung between verses of psalms.

bonuses.leadin: A labor union led by Sarah Bagley published the Voice of Industry newspaper in this town in the 1840s. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this town. Harriet Hanson Robinson's autobiography recounts Robinson's involvement in a strike called a "turn-out" in this town.

The Lowell system of production was adopted in the United States during the expansion of this industry. The "Father of the American Industrial Revolution," Samuel Slater, brought British technology for this industry to America.

During the peak output of the Lowell mills, many second- and third-generation millworkers sought middle-class employment and were replaced by people fleeing this event, who suffered 30% mortality on unsanitary ships known as "long cónra."
answers: textile industry [or fabric; prompt on fiber; prompt on yarn; prompt on clothing]
Irish Potato Famine [or Great Famine; or an Gorta Mór; or Great Hunger; prompt on the Famine]

bonuses.leadin: Christian mistrust on account of Jewish recital of this statement motivated medieval oaths sworn more Judaico (MOR-ay jew-DAY-ick-oh). For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this legal declaration made on the eve of Yom Kippur to absolve those who recite it of "all vows," as its Aramaic title suggests.

This Gileadite vowed to give whatever comes out of his house to meet him as a burnt offering if he defeated the Ammonites, leading to a yearly custom in which Israelite women lamented this judge's sacrificed daughter.

The Kol Nidre may have originated as the hatarat nedarim said right before this holiday, which begins the High Holy Days. Apples dipped in honey are eaten during this two-day celebration of the Jewish New Year.
answers: Rosh Hashanah [or Yom Teruah; or Yom HaDin; or Yom HaZikaron]
formatted_answers: Rosh Hashanah [or Yom Teruah; or Yom HaDin; or Yom HaZikaron]

bonuses.leadin: This author wrote that "you will love again the stranger who was your self" in "Love After Love." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author, who created an epic retelling of the Homeric myths set on St. Lucia in his poem Omeros.

This Walcott poem ponders, "How can I face such slaughter and be cool?" after wondering how to choose between the title place and "the English tongue I love." This poem begins by describing a wind "ruffling the tawny pelt" of its title place.
In an oft-quoted line from "A Far Cry From Africa," the conflict between Africa and England is represented using these two conflicting figures, one of which "wrestles with" the other. Name both.
answers: the gorilla wrestles with the superman [answers may be given in either order, but do not accept or prompt if only one answer is given]
formatted_answers: the gorilla wrestles with the superman [answers may be given in either order, but do not accept or prompt if only one answer is given]

bonuses.leadin: Though this clergyman is credited with introducing the Black Rubric into the Book of Common Prayer, his followers switched to a book titled The Form of Prayers after being expelled. For 10 points each:
parts: The Book of Common Order is also called the namesake liturgy of what author of The First Blast of the Trumpet Against the Monstrous Regiment of Women?

Knox's Presbyterian Church of Scotland was theologically aligned with this other group, whose churches in the Channel Islands were organized by Thomas Cartwright. A Genevan burgomaster likely is the source of the name for these French Calvinists.
The Free Presbyterian Church of Ulster was founded by this longtime leader and founder of the DUP, who interrupted a speech in the European Parliament to denounce Pope John Paul II as the Antichrist.
answers: Ian Paisley [or Ian Richard Kyle Paisley, Baron Bannside]
formatted_answers: Ian Paisley [or Ian Richard Kyle Paisley, Baron Bannside]

bonuses.leadin: This force's potential varies with radius squared within a solid uniform sphere. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this force, which near to Earth's surface gives rise to a potential energy equal to "m g h."
More generally, gravitational potential can be found by solving a form of Poisson's ("PWAH-sohn's") equation that sets this function of the gravitational potential equal to "4 pi G rho."

In symmetric cases, it can be useful to note that Poisson's equation is equivalent to the integral form of this law for gravity, which states that the surface integral of gravitational field strength is proportional to the mass enclosed. It shares its name with a similar law from electromagnetism.

bonuses.leadin: A critic from this country claimed a planned building was "made of glass, steel, and revolution." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country where Vladimir Tatlin designed a never-completed Monument to the Third International for the Comintern.

This American artist created thirty-nine "Monuments for V. Tatlin" shaped like the Monument to the Third International. This artist's "icons" are fluorescent light installations inspired by William of Ockham's nominalism.

This artist created the Fountain of Light based on the design of the Monument to the Third International for the Louvre Abu Dhabi. The photograph series Study of Perspective shows this artist giving the middle finger to many world monuments.
answers: Soviet Union [or USSR; or Union of Soviet Socialist Republics; prompt on Russia]
formatted_answers: Soviet Union [or USSR; or Union of Soviet Socialist Republics; prompt on Russia]

bonuses.leadin: At Katherine Dunham's namesake School in New York City, Marie Bryant taught this dance style alongside boogie-woogie. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this African American dance style, the signature of Bojangles Robinson and Gregory Hines. After the film Roberta, the sound of Fred Astaire performing in this style was added in post-production.
Dunham choreographed the posthumous 1972 premiere of this composer's opera Treemonisha. Pieces by this composer title Kenneth MacMillan's Elite Syncopations and Martha Graham's Maple Leaf Rag.

This composer won an Oscar for scoring Joplin's music for the Paul Newman and Robert Redford film The Sting. Due to a shared 1975 Drama Pulitzer, this composer of A Chorus Line joins Richard Rodgers as one of only two people to garner a "PEGOT."

bonuses.leadin: In a play, Mathilde von Zahnd reveals that she has been copying documents from a character with this profession for years. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this profession of a character who develops the "Principle of Universal Discovery." In that play titled for this profession, two Cold War spies claim to be members of this profession in order to fake insanity.
The Physicists is by Friedrich Dürrenmatt, an author from this country. In another play, a hero from this country kills the tyrannical governor Gessler.

In The Physicists, Mathilde believes that this man is guiding her actions. The climactic scene of Brecht's The Caucasian Chalk Circle was inspired by a story in which this Biblical ruler ordered a baby to be split in half to determine its real mother.
answers: physicists [accept The Physicists or Die Physiker; prompt on scientists or researchers]
Switzerland [or Swiss Confederation] [The second play is William Tell.]
formatted_answers: physicists [accept The Physicists or Die Physiker; prompt on scientists or researchers]
Switzerland [or Swiss Confederation] [The second play is William Tell.]

bonuses.leadin: In this novel, Ugwu writes the book The World Was Silent While We Died. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this novel set during the Biafran War, in which Kainene forgives her twin sister Olanna for drunkenly seducing Richard, before disappearing after crossing enemy lines.
This Nigerian author wrote Half of a Yellow Sun, as well as Purple Hibiscus.

In this Booker Prize-winning novel by a fellow Nigerian author, the spirit child Azaro visits Madame Koto's bar, while Azaro's father attempts to become a boxer. The Party of the Poor opposes the Party of the Rich in this novel.
